de.ovgu.featureide.fm.core.base

Interface IFeatureModel

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.lang.Cloneable, IEventManager
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    ExtendedFeatureModel, FeatureModel

    public interface IFeatureModel
extends java.lang.Cloneable, IEventManager
    The feature model interface represents any class that acts in the sense of a feature model in FeatureIDE.

    A feature model contains of a modifiable collection of
    • Features, and
    • Constraints of features

    Each feature in a feature model has a unique identifier and is related to other features over some expressions and relations which forms the feature model (such as parent-children relation with implication expression from one feature to another). Additional to the structure of features (see IFeature and IFeatureStructure for more details) inside the feature models tree, features relationships can be further expressed using constraints. While the feature structure is bound to the actual feature model tree, constraints can be state restrictions and relations to arbitrary features inside the feature model.

    Features inside a feature model can by analyzed in order to determine feature properties which are implicated by the structure, the statements, and the constraints. As a result of such an analysis, a set of dead features can be found for instance. For more information about analysis, see FeatureModelAnalyzer.

    Additional to the collection mentioned above, the feature model contains properties to express
    • Annotations
    • Comments
    • Feature Orders

    A feature model is moreover related to it's project, such that the project's name can be received, the related composer extension can be received, as well as certain event handling logic (such as model data change event handling) can be made. Furthermore, each feature model is required to has an own unique system-wide identifier (at least during runtime). Any implementation of this interface has to provide the corresponding getId() method and have to implement the management of identifiers among a set of feature models.

    Any feature model is intended to be instantiated by a corresponding factory, the implementation-specific IFeatureModelFactory.

    FeatureIDE provides a default implementation FeatureModel which is used for default use-cases and can be customized via inheritance of FeatureModel and a user-defined feature model factory. Internally, a feature model is represented by an unique numeric identifier, which should be considered in the related IFeatureModelFactory in order to avoid confusion with other models.

    Example
    The following example demonstrate the creation of a new feature model using FeatureIDE's default FeatureModel implementation FeatureModel, and the corresponding default factory DefaultFeatureModelFactory over the conviennent factory class FMFactoryManager: IFeatureModel model = FMFactoryManager.getFactory().createFeatureModel(); A unified handling of certain IFeature, and IFeatureModel implementations (in terms of conviennent methods) can be achieved with the use of FeatureUtils helper class.

    Caching notes: A feature model implementation using the IFeatureModel interface has to provide a map of feature names to the corresponding feature objects, the feature table. This data structure is used in the RenamingsManager for instance. If the implementation utilizes this data structure for internal use, modifications to this data structure must be protected against concurrent accesses. The default implementations FeatureModel uses a ConcurrentHashMap for this purpose.

    API notes: The classes internal structure has heavily changed compared to older FeatureIDE version. A bridge to the old-fashioned handling is available in FeatureUtils as static methods.

    Notes on thread safeness: At least the management of IFeature and IFeatureModel identifiers (e.g., getting the next free id) have to be thread safe. The reference default implementation for feature models is private static long NEXT_ID = 0; protected static final synchronized long getNextId() { return NEXT_ID++; }

    Compatibility Notes: To provide compatibility to earlier versions of FeatureIDE, the out-dated class FeatureModel is now a wrapper to an IFeatureModel instance (but incompatible to it) and make use of convert-functionalities inside FeatureUtils.
    Since:
    3.0
    Author:
    Sebastian Krieter, Marcus Pinnecke
    See Also:
    Default implementation of IFeatureModel (as starting point for custom implementations), Interface for features (IFeature), Interface for feature constraints (IConstraint), Interface for feature properties (IFeatureProperty), Interface for a feature's structure (IFeatureStructure), Default implementation for features (Feature), Default implementation for feature constraints (AConstraint), Default implementation for feature properties (FeatureProperty), Default implementation for a feature's structure (FeatureStructure)

    • Method Detail

      • getId

        long getId()
        Feature models are identified with their system-wide unique numeric identifier. This methods returns the identifier of the current feature model. Custom implementations might manage the feature model's identifier similar to the default implementation: private static long NEXT_ID = 0; protected static final synchronized long getNextId() { return NEXT_ID++; } The identifier has to be used for comparisons using Object.equals(Object).
        Returns:
        unique identifier
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        getNextElementId()

      • getFactoryID

        java.lang.String getFactoryID()
        A feature model is created via a feature model factory. This methods returns the identifier of the factory used to create this feature model. The factory can be used to create more feature models, features, or constraint from the same type as this feature model.
        Returns:
        the feature model factory ID.
        Since:
        3.1
        See Also:
        FMFactoryManager.getFactoryById(String)

      • addConstraint

        void addConstraint(IConstraint constraint)
        A constraint is an additional restriction on features in the feature model. This methods adds the constraint constraint to the end of the existing collection. Please note that
        • the specification do not require a check if constraint is null. However, for regular use, constraint is assumed to be non-null
        • the specification do not require a check of duplicates. In FeatureIDE's default implementation, the collection is managed using a List. For regular use case, this collection is assumed to be duplicate-free. Therefore, duplicates should not be added.
        To add a constraint at a specific position, use addConstraint(IConstraint, int)
        Parameters:
        constraint - The constraint to be added at the end of the existing collection
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        addConstraint(IConstraint, int), getConstraintCount(), getConstraintIndex(IConstraint), getConstraints(), removeConstraint(IConstraint), removeConstraint(int), setConstraint(int, IConstraint), setConstraints(Iterable), replaceConstraint(IConstraint, int)

      • addConstraint

        void addConstraint(IConstraint constraint,
                   int index)
        A constraint is an additional restriction on features in the feature model. This methods adds the constraint constraint at the given index of the existing collection. Please note that
        • the specification do not require a check if constraint is null. However, for regular use, constraint is assumed to be non-null
        • the specification do not require a check of duplicates. In FeatureIDE's default implementation, the collection is managed using a List. For regular use case, this collection is assumed to be duplicate-free. Therefore, duplicates should not be added.
        To add a constraint at a specific position, use addConstraint(IConstraint, int)
        Parameters:
        constraint - The constraint to be added at position index of the existing collection
        index - The position. It is assumed, that the index is valid. Otherwise a exception have to be thrown by the implementation.
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        addConstraint(IConstraint), getConstraintCount(), getConstraintIndex(IConstraint), getConstraints(), removeConstraint(IConstraint), removeConstraint(int), setConstraint(int, IConstraint), setConstraints(Iterable), replaceConstraint(IConstraint, int)

      • addFeature

        boolean addFeature(IFeature feature)
        Add a new feature feature to this feature model. If the feature model not contains a feature with the name IFeatureModelElement.getName() of feature, the feature will be added and the method returns true. Otherwise, the feature is not added and the method returns false. Classes implementing IFeatureModel must provide consistency with the underlying feature table which is accessible by getFeatureTable().
        Parameters:
        feature - the feature to be added. feature is assumed to be non-null
        Returns:
        true if the feature was added, otherwise false.
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        deleteFeature(IFeature), getFeature(CharSequence), getFeatures(), getNumberOfFeatures(), reset()

      • clone

        IFeatureModel clone(IFeature newRoot)
        Clones this feature model f, such that a new instance f' is created. The cloned feature model f' must satisfy the following properties to contain the same information as f:
        • the identifiers of f and f' must be identical
        • the feature order list of f and f' must be equal, but the references must be different
        • the user defined feature order flag of f and f' must be identical
        • the feature models properties must be equal but with different references in f and f'
        • the feature models constraints must be equal but with different references in f and f'
        • the cloned feature model f' must contain the structure behind newRoot but with different references
        • the cloned feature model f''s root feature must be newRoot
        Additionally, the following must hold f != f' and f.equals(f').
        Parameters:
        newRoot - the new root feature including the entire structure of newRoot for the cloned model
        Returns:
        A new equal instance of this feature model with different references and newRoot as root feature
        Since:
        3.0

      • createDefaultValues

        void createDefaultValues(java.lang.CharSequence projectName)
        Resets this feature model to the default values. The parameter projectName will be used as the new root features name if there are no features in this model (the feature table is empty). Independent of this, a new feature called Base will be added as child of the feature models root feature, and the feature models root feature will be set as abstract feature.
        Parameters:
        projectName - the name for the root feature, if this feature model does not contain any features. Otherwise this parameter will be ignored. If projectName is an empty string, the string "Root" will be used for the potential new root feature. The parameter projectName is assumed to be non-null
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        reset()

      • deleteFeature

        boolean deleteFeature(IFeature feature)
        Removes feature from this model. feature can not be removed, if it is the feature models root feature or if it is not contained in this model. In both cases, the method returns false. Otherwise the method returns true.

        Implementations of this method must ensure, that after removing feature, the feature's parent feature is changed to an and ( or, alternative) group if feature was an and (or, alternative) group. Additionally, removing feature has to add the children of feature as children to the parent feature.

        Removing a feature also removes this feature from the feature table and the feature order list. Both must be consistent with getFeatureOrderList() and getFeatureOrderList()

        NoteIf the structure should not be changed, use deleteFeatureFromTable(IFeature)
        Parameters:
        feature - the feature that should be removed. It is assumed to be non-null
        Returns:
        false if feature is the models root feature, or if feature is not contained in this model. Otherwise true.
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        addFeature(IFeature), getFeature(CharSequence), getFeatures(), getNumberOfFeatures(), reset()

      • deleteFeatureFromTable

        void deleteFeatureFromTable(IFeature feature)
        Removes the feature feature from the feature table by feature's name with IFeatureModelElement.getName(). If the feature table does not contain a feature with such a name, there will be no changes.

        This method only affects the collection of features stored in the feature model, but do not change the structure neither of feature nor it's parent or children.

        Note There is no equality check over the identifiers between the feature to be deleted and the feature contained in the collection, expect for equality in their names. To avoid confusion, this check should be done before calling this method.
        Note If the structure should be changed, use deleteFeature(IFeature)
        Parameters:
        feature - the feature (the feature's name) which should be deleted from the feature table
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        setFeatureTable(Hashtable), getFeatureTable()

      • getAnalyser

        FeatureModelAnalyzer getAnalyser()
        Returns an instance of FeatureModelAnalyzer which is bound to this feature model. Since analysis of feature models are computational expensive in general, results for analysis are cached in the instance of a analyzer. When calling methods on the return value of this method, changes are indirectly automatically stored in this feature model by object references.
        Returns:
        The instance of FeatureModelAnalyzer bound to this feature model.
        Since:
        3.0

      • getConstraintIndex

        int getConstraintIndex(IConstraint constraint)
        Returns the index of the first occurrence of constraint in the collection of constraints, or -1 if constraint is not contained.

        Note:
        Parameters:
        constraint - the element to be removed. It is assumed that this parameter is non-null
        Returns:
        the index of the first occurrence of constraint in the collection of constraints, or -1 otherwise.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - - if constraint is null (optional)
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        addConstraint(IConstraint), addConstraint(IConstraint, int), getConstraintCount(), getConstraints(), removeConstraint(IConstraint), removeConstraint(int), setConstraint(int, IConstraint), setConstraints(Iterable), replaceConstraint(IConstraint, int)

      • getConstraints

        java.util.List<IConstraint> getConstraints()
        Returns the list of constraints stored in this feature model.

        Note: The returned list should be unmodifiable to avoid external access to internal data
        Returns:
        All constraints stored in this feature model.
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        addConstraint(IConstraint), addConstraint(IConstraint, int), getConstraintCount(), getConstraintIndex(IConstraint), removeConstraint(IConstraint), removeConstraint(int), setConstraint(int, IConstraint), setConstraints(Iterable), replaceConstraint(IConstraint, int)

      • getFeature

        IFeature getFeature(java.lang.CharSequence name)
        Returns the feature with the given name stored in this feature model, or null if no features can be found. The given name is compared to the names of the contained features in a case-sensitive manner. Therefore "FeatureA" is unequal to featureA.
        Parameters:
        name - the name (case sensitive) of the feature which should be return. This parameter is assumed to be non-null.
        Returns:
        the associated feature, if there is a match to name, or null otherwise.
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        addFeature(IFeature), deleteFeature(IFeature), getFeatures(), getNumberOfFeatures(), reset()

      • getFeatureOrderList

        java.util.List<java.lang.String> getFeatureOrderList()
        Returns the ordered collection of feature names according to the given feature order. If an order is given, the method returns the corresponding list of feature names according to their order. If no order is set, the method returns the names of features according to a pre-order traversation of the root feature's structure. In both cases, the resulting collection is unmodifiable.
        Returns:
        an ordered list of feature names, either as a given order or in pre-order by traversing the root-feature.
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        setFeatureOrderList(List), setFeatureOrderListItem(int, String), setFeatureOrderUserDefined(boolean)

      • getFeatures

        java.lang.Iterable<IFeature> getFeatures()
        Returns the a read-only iterable collection of features stored in this feature model. This method is intend to provide the iteration-concept directly.

        Example for (IFeature feature : featureModel.getFeatures()) { // ... } If a list interface is required rather than the iterable counterpart, the utility class Functional provides a set of useful methods. To convert the iterator directly into a list, use Functional.toList(Iterable). By using methods from the Functional utility class the advantages of a functional-like programming style can be directly used. For instance, to convert the collection of features inside a feature model into a set of feature names, the following code snippet can be used:

        import static de.ovgu.featureide.fm.core.functional.Functional.*;
        Set<String> featureNames = new HashSet<>(toList(mapToString(fm.getFeatures())))
        If modification is required, use the related constructor for collection implementations, e.g.,
        List<IFeature> list = new LinkedList<IFeature>(Functional.toList(fm.getFeatures()));
        Note: Many operations of features in feature models runs over iteration. This method returns an iterator rather than a collection for lazy evaluation purposes.
        Returns:
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        FeatureIDE functional helper class, addFeature(IFeature), deleteFeature(IFeature), getFeature(CharSequence), getNumberOfFeatures(), reset()

      • getVisibleFeatures

        java.lang.Iterable<IFeature> getVisibleFeatures(boolean showHiddenFeatures)
        Returns the a read-only iterable collection of features stored in this feature model, which are not hidden and not collapsed. This method is intend to provide the iteration-concept directly.

        Example for (IFeature feature : featureModel.getVisibleFeatures()) { // ... } If a list interface is required rather than the iterable counterpart, the utility class Functional provides a set of useful methods. To convert the iterator directly into a list, use Functional.toList(Iterable). By using methods from the Functional utility class the advantages of a functional-like programming style can be directly used. For instance, to convert the collection of features inside a feature model into a set of feature names, the following code snippet can be used: import static de.ovgu.featureide.fm.core.functional.Functional.*; Set<String> featureNames = new HashSet<>(toList(mapToString(fm.getVisibleFeatures()))) If modification is required, use the related constructor for collection implementations, e.g.,
        List<IFeature> list = new LinkedList<IFeature>(Functional.toList(fm.getVisibleFeatures()));
        Note: Many operations of features in feature models runs over iteration. This method returns an iterator rather than a collection for lazy evaluation purposes.
        Returns:
        A iterable of IFeatures, which are not hidden and not collapsed
        Since:
        3.3
        See Also:
        FeatureIDE functional helper class, addFeature(IFeature), deleteFeature(IFeature), getFeature(CharSequence), getNumberOfFeatures(), reset()

      • getNumberOfFeatures

        int getNumberOfFeatures()
        Returns the number of features stored in this feature model. This call must be constistent with getFeatureTable() size.
        Returns:
        number of feature stored in this model
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        addFeature(IFeature), deleteFeature(IFeature), getFeature(CharSequence), getFeatures(), reset()

      • getProperty

        IFeatureModelProperty getProperty()
        Returns the model properties attached to this feature model. These properties contain at least
        • Annotations
        • Comments
        • The feature order specification
        The properties returned by this model is implementation specific and might contain additional properties (see IFeatureModelProperty).
        Returns:
        feature model properties
        Since:
        3.0

      • getStructure

        IFeatureModelStructure getStructure()
        Returns the feature models IFeatureModelStructure instance. In this features can be received in preorder, and further structural properties can be get. For instance, the structure holds information if alternative groups are contained, or the number of or-groups in total. For more information, see IFeatureModelStructure.
        Returns:
        This feature model's structure
        Since:
        3.0

      • removeConstraint

        void removeConstraint(IConstraint constraint)
        Removes the first occurrence of constraint from the collection of constraints in this model, if it is present. Otherwise there is no effect to this model.
        Parameters:
        constraint - The constraint to be removed
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        addConstraint(IConstraint), addConstraint(IConstraint, int), getConstraintCount(), getConstraintIndex(IConstraint), getConstraints(), removeConstraint(int), setConstraint(int, IConstraint), setConstraints(Iterable), replaceConstraint(IConstraint, int)

      • removeConstraint

        void removeConstraint(int index)
        Removes the constraint at the specified position index in this collection of constraints in this model. When a constraint was removed, the remaining constraints to the right are shifted one position to the left.
        Parameters:
        index - position of the constraint to be removed
        Throws:
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - If the index is out of range
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        addConstraint(IConstraint), addConstraint(IConstraint, int), getConstraintCount(), getConstraintIndex(IConstraint), getConstraints(), removeConstraint(IConstraint), setConstraint(int, IConstraint), setConstraints(Iterable), replaceConstraint(IConstraint, int)

      • replaceConstraint

        void replaceConstraint(IConstraint constraint,
                       int index)
        Replaces the constraint constraint at the specified position index in the collection of constraints of this feature model.
        Parameters:
        constraint - constraint which should be stored at index
        index - position for replacement
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if constraint is null
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the index is out of range
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        addConstraint(IConstraint), addConstraint(IConstraint, int), getConstraintCount(), getConstraintIndex(IConstraint), getConstraints(), removeConstraint(IConstraint), removeConstraint(int), setConstraint(int, IConstraint), setConstraints(Iterable)

      • reset

        void reset()
        Set the feature models structure root element to null and clears the collections of features and constraints. Moreover, the feature order list is cleared and all properties. The next unique element identifier is also reseted to 0, such that getNextElementId() will return 0.
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        deleteFeature(IFeature), removeConstraint(int), removeConstraint(IConstraint), createDefaultValues(CharSequence)

      • setConstraints

        void setConstraints(java.lang.Iterable<IConstraint> constraints)
        Sets the collections of constraints to the ones yielded by constraints. Existing constraint in the collection will be removed before this operation.
        Parameters:
        constraints - Source of constraints which should be copied into this feature model
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        addConstraint(IConstraint), addConstraint(IConstraint, int), getConstraintCount(), getConstraintIndex(IConstraint), getConstraints(), removeConstraint(IConstraint), removeConstraint(int), setConstraint(int, IConstraint), replaceConstraint(IConstraint, int), Setting an empty iterable

      • setFeatureOrderList

        void setFeatureOrderList(java.util.List<java.lang.String> featureOrderList)
        Sets the list of feature names for ordering purposed to the content provided by featureOrderList. Existing ordering will be removed before this operation is executed. There is no check if the feature names provided by featureOrderList actually reflects names of features stored in this model.

        The order of strings provided in featureOrderList provide the order of feature names.
        Parameters:
        featureOrderList - the orderd list of feature names which provides the feature order. This parameter is assumed to be non-null
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        getFeatureOrderList(), setFeatureOrderListItem(int, String), setFeatureOrderUserDefined(boolean)

      • setFeatureOrderUserDefined

        void setFeatureOrderUserDefined(boolean featureOrderUserDefined)
        Sets a flag that specificities if the feature order in this feature model user defined or not.
        Parameters:
        featureOrderUserDefined - flag to indicate user defined ordering
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        getFeatureOrderList(), setFeatureOrderList(List), setFeatureOrderListItem(int, String)

      • setFeatureTable

        void setFeatureTable(java.util.Hashtable<java.lang.String,IFeature> featureTable)
        Overwrites the contents of the feature table with the given featureTable. The existing feature table will be cleared and each element in featureTable will be inserted in the feature model's underlying feature table. There is no check, if the the mapping of features names to features in featureTable is consistent. Moreover, there is no check if the feature names in featureTable corresponds to the feature names in this feature model. Therefore, overwriting the contents of the feature table by this function might lead to unexpected behavior, when not used correctly.
        Parameters:
        featureTable - New feature table for this feature model. This parameter is assumed to be non-null
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        deleteFeatureFromTable(IFeature), getFeatureTable()

      • getFeatureTable

        java.util.Map<java.lang.String,IFeature> getFeatureTable()
        Returns:
        Returns this feature model's underlying feature table as an unmodifiable map.
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        setFeatureTable(Hashtable), deleteFeatureFromTable(IFeature)

      • clone

        IFeatureModel clone()
        Clones this feature model f to a new instance of feature model f', such that f != f' and f.equals(f') holds. More in detail:
        • Both feature model's unique identifiers are equal
        • Both feature order lists are equal but their references aren't identical
        • Both feature order lists user defined order flag is equal
        • Both feature order lists property and structure are equal, but their references aren't identical
        • Both feature model's source files are equal but their references aren't identical
        • Both feature model's feature structure (including their constraints) are equal but their references aren't identical
        • The feature model f'' feature model analyzer instance is a new instance
        Returns:
        cloned instance of this model, such that the new instance is equal to this feature model but their references aren't identical
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        getId(), getFeatureOrderList(), isFeatureOrderUserDefined(), getStructure(), getProperty(), getSourceFile(), getStructure(), getConstraints(), getAnalyser()

      • getUndoContext

        java.lang.Object getUndoContext()
        Returns the modifiable undo-context of this feature model. To undo-context enables undoing of actions performed to this feature model, such as renaming or feature removing over the user interface. The undo context is intended to work streamlessly with the eclipse framework used, e.g., in the FeatureDiagramEditor feature model diagram editor.
        Returns:
        undo-context of this feature model
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        setUndoContext(Object)

      • setUndoContext

        void setUndoContext(java.lang.Object undoContext)
        Sets the modifiable undo-context of this feature model. To undo-context enables undoing of actions performed to this feature model, such as renaming or feature removing over the user interface. The undo context is intended to work streamlessly with the eclipse framework used, e.g., in the FeatureDiagramEditor feature model diagram editor.
        Parameters:
        undoContext -
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        getUndoContext()

      • setFeatureOrderListItem

        void setFeatureOrderListItem(int i,
                             java.lang.String newName)
        Replaces the feature order item at the specified position i in this feature model's feature order list with the specified element newName.
        Parameters:
        i - index of the element to replace
        newName - new name to be stored at the specified position
        Throws:
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the index is out of range
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        getFeatureOrderList(), setFeatureOrderList(List), setFeatureOrderUserDefined(boolean)

      • setSourceFile

        void setSourceFile(java.nio.file.Path file)
        Set the feature models source file to file. By definition, the feature model's unique identifier is bidirectional mapped to the source files. Therefore, two feature model's based on the same file must have to same unique identifier. The feature model's identifier will not be changed, if file is null.

        The default implementation provides this mechanism by using ModelFileIdMap, such that: this.sourceFile = file; if (file != null) { id = ModelFileIdMap.getModelId(this, file); } Note: The specification does not require to reload the content of this feature model, when the source file is changes. Hence, using this method only will affect the return value of getSourceFile() and perhaps getId(). However, it is not intended to notify listeners about this change.
        Parameters:
        file - the source file of this model (might be null.
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        getSourceFile(), ModelFileIdMap.getModelId(IFeatureModel, Path)

      • getSourceFile

        java.nio.file.Path getSourceFile()
        Returns:
        Returns the feature models current source file, or null if no source file is specified.
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        setSourceFile(Path)

      • getNextElementId

        long getNextElementId()
        Feature models are identified with their system-wide unique numeric identifier. This methods returns the next free identifier of the current feature model and is a state-full operation, such that invoking the method twice will result in two other numeric identifiers.

        The default implementations provides this by the following code snippet: private static long NEXT_ID = 0; protected static final synchronized long getNextId() { return NEXT_ID++; } Notes to thread-safe execution: The management of receiving the next free identifier must be thread-safe.
        Returns:
        the next free system-wide unique identifier for feature models
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        getId()

      • setConstraint

        void setConstraint(int index,
                   IConstraint constraint)
        Overwrites the constraint stored in this feature model at position index with the constraint provided by the parameter constraint.
        Parameters:
        index - index of the constraint to replace
        constraint - constraint to be stored at the specified position
        Throws:
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the index is out of range
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        addConstraint(IConstraint), addConstraint(IConstraint, int), getConstraintCount(), getConstraintIndex(IConstraint), getConstraints(), removeConstraint(IConstraint), removeConstraint(int), setConstraints(Iterable), replaceConstraint(IConstraint, int)
